text: O tawny Bull, thus showing forth thy nature, as neither to be wroth, O God, nor slay us. Here, Rudra, listen to our invocation. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly. Next: HYMN XXXIV. Maruts

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Maruts of resistless might who love the rain, resplendent, terrible like wild beasts in their strength, Glowing like flames of fire, impetuous in career, blowing the wandering rain-cloud, have disclosed the kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They gleam with armlets as the heavens are decked with stars, like cloud-born lightnings shine the torrents of their rain. Since the strong Rudra, O Maruts with brilliant chests, sprang into life for you in Pṛśni's radiant lap.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They drip like horses in the racings of swift steeds; with the stream's rapid cars they hasten on their way. Maruts with helms of gold, ye who make all things shake, come with your spotted deer, one-minded, to our food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They have bestowed of Mitra all that live, to feed, they who for evermore cause their swift drops to flow; Whose steeds are spotted deer, whose riches never fail, like horses in full speed, bound to the pole in work.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With brightly-flaming kine whose udders swell with milk, with glittering lances on your unobstructed paths, O Maruts, of one mind, like swans who seek their nests, come to the rapturous enjoyment of the meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To these our prayers, O Maruts, come unanimous, come ye to our libations like the praise of men. Make it swell like a mare, in udder like a cow, and for the singer grace the song with plenteous strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Give us a steed, O Maruts mighty in the car; prevailing prayer that brings remembrance day by day; Food to your praisers, to your bard in deeds of might give winning wisdom, power uninjured, unsurpassed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the bright-chested Maruts, lavish of their gifts, bind at the time bliss their horses to the cars, Then, as the milch-cow feeds her calf within the stalls, they pour forth food for all oblation-bringing men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Save us, O Maruts, Vasus, from the injurer, the mortal foe who makes us looked upon as wolves. With chariot all aflame compass him round about: O Rudras, cast away the foeman's deadly bolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Well-known, ye Maruts, is that wondrous course of yours, when they milked Pṛśni's udder, close akin to her. Or when to shame the bard who lauded, Rudra's Sons, ye O infallible brought Trita to decay.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We call you such, great Maruts, following wonted ways, to the oblation paid to Viṣṇu Speeder-on. With ladles lifted up, with prayer, we seek of them preeminent, golden-hued, the wealth which all extol.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They, the Daśagvas, first of all brought sacrifice: they at the break of mornings shall inspirit us. Dawn with her purple beams uncovereth the nights, with great light glowing like a billowy sea of milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Rudras have rejoiced them in the gathered bands at seats of worship as in purple ornaments. They with impetuous vigour sending down the rain have taken to themselves a bright and lovely hue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soliciting their high protection for our help, with this our adoration we sing praise to them, Whom, for assistance, like the five terrestrial priests. Trita hath brought to aid us hither on his car.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So may your favouring help be turned to us-ward, your kindness like a lowing cow approach us, Wherewith ye bear your servant over trouble, and free your worshipper from scoff and scorning. Next: HYMN XXXV. Son of Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: EAGER for spoil my flow of speech I utter: may the Floods' Child accept my songs with favour. Will not the rapid Son of Waters make them lovely, for he it is who shall enjoy them?

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him let us address the song well-fashioned, forth from the heart. Shall he not understand it' The friendly Son of Waters by the greatness of Godhead hath produced all things existing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Some floods unite themselves and others join them: die sounding rivers fill one common storehouse. On every side the bright Floods have encompassed the bright resplendent Offspring of the Waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The never-sullen waters, youthful Maidens, carefully decking, wait on him the youthful. He with bright rays shines forth in splendid beauty, unfed with wood, in waters, oil-enveloped.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him three Dames are offering food to feed him, Goddesses to the God whom none may injure. Within the waters hath he pressed, as hollows, and drinks their milk who now are first made mothers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Here was the horse's birth; his was the sunlight. Save thou our princes from the oppressor's onslaught. Him, indestructible, dwelling at a distance in forts unwrought lies and ill spirits reach not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, in whose mansion is the teeming Milch-cow, swells the Gods’ nectar and cats noble viands. The Son of Waters, gathering strength in waters, shines for his worshipper to give him treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who in waters with his own pure Godhead shines widely, law-abiding, everlasting— The other worlds are verily his branches, and plants are born of him with all their offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Waters’ Son hath risen, and clothed in lightning ascended up unto the curled cloud's bosom; And bearing with them his supremest glory the Youthful Ones, gold-coloured, move around him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Golden in form is he, like gold to look on, his colour is like gold, the Son of Waters. When he is seated fresh from golden birthplace those who present their gold give food to feed him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This the fair name and this the lovely aspect of him the Waters’ Son increase in secret. Whom here the youthful Maids together kindle, his food is sacred oil of golden colour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him, nearest Friend of many, will we worship with sacrifice. and reverence and oblation. I make his back to shine, with chips provide him; I offer food and with my songs exalt him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bull hath laid his own life-germ Within them. He sucks them as an infant, and they kiss him. He, Son of Waters, of unfading colour, hath entered here as in another's body.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While here he dwelleth in sublimest station, resplendent with the rays that never perish, The Waters, bearing oil to feed their offspring, flow, Youthful Ones, in wanderings about him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, I gave good shelter to the people, and to the princes goodly preparation. Blessed is all that Gods regard with favour. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly. Next: HYMN XXXVI Various Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WATER and milk hath he endued, sent forth to thee: the men have drained him with the filters and the stones. Drink, Indra, from the Hotar's bowl—first right is thine—Soma hallowed and poured with Vaṣaṭ and Svāhā.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Busied with sacrifice, with spotted deer and spears, gleaming upon your way with ornaments, yea, our Friends, Sitting on sacred grass, ye Sons of Bhārata, drink Soma from the Potar's bowl, O Men of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Come unto us, ye swift to listen: as at home upon the sacred grass sit and enjoy yourselves. And, Tvaṣṭar, well-content be joyful in the juice with Gods and Goddesses in gladsome company.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring the Gods hither, Sage, and offer sacrifice: at the three altars seat thee willingly, O Priest. Accept for thy delight the proffered Soma meath: drink from the Kindler's bowl and fill thee with thy share.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This is the strengthener of thy body's manly might: strength, victory for all time are placed within thine arms. Pressed for thee, Maghavan, it is offered unto thee: drink from the chalice of this Brahman, drink thy fill.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Accept the sacrifice; mark both of you, my call: the Priest hath seated him after the ancient texts. My prayer that bids them come goes forth to both the Kings: drink ye the Soma meath from the Director's bowl. Next: HYMN XXXVII. Various Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Enjoy thy fill of meath out of the Hotar's cup: Adhvaryus he desires a full draught poured for him. Bring it him: seeking this he gives. Granter of Wealth, drink Soma with the Ṛtus from the Hotar's cup.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He whom of old I called on, him I call on now. He is to be invoked; his name is He who Gives, Here brought by priests is Soma meath. Granter of Wealth, drink Soma with the Ṛtus from the Potar's cup.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fat may the horses be wherewith thou speedest on: Lord of the Wood, unharming, strengthen thou thyself. Drawing and seizing, Bold One, thou who grantest wealth, drink Soma with the Ṛtus from the Neṣṭar's cup.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From Hotar's cup and Potar's he hath drunk and joyed: the proffered food hath pleased him from the Neṣṭar's bowl. The fourth cup undisturbed, immortal, let him drink who giveth wealth, the cup of the wealth-giving God.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yoke, O ye Twain, to-day your hero-bearing car, swift-moving hitherward: your loosing-place is here. Mix the oblations, then come hither with the meath, and drink the Soma, ye rich in abundant strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, accept the fuel and our offered gift: accept the prayer of man, accept our eulogy, Do thou with all, with Ṛtu, O thou Excellent, fain, make the great Gods all fain taste the gift we bring. Next: HYMN XXXVIII. Savitar.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Having gone up on high, the God broad-handed spreads his arms widely forth that all may mark him. Even the waters bend them to his service: even this wind rests in the circling region.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Though borne by swift steeds he will yet unyoke them: e’en the fleet chariot hath he stayed from going. He hath checked e’en their haste who glide like serpents. Night closely followed Savitar's dominion.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What was spread out she weaves afresh, re-weaving: the skilful leaves his labour half-completed. He hath arisen from rest, and parted seasons: Savitar hath approached, God, holy-minded.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through various dwellings, through entire existence, spreads, manifest, the household light of Agni. The Mother gives her Son the goodliest portion, and Savitar hath sped to meet his summons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He comes again, unfolded, fain for conquest: at home was he, the love of all things moving. Each man hath come leaving his evil doings, after the Godlike Savitar's commandment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The wild beasts spread through desert places seeking their watery share which thou hast set in waters. The woods are given to the birds. These statutes of the God Savitar none disobeyeth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With utmost speed, in restless haste at sunset Varuṇa seeks his watery habitation. Then seeks each bird his nest, each beast his lodging. In due place Savitar hath set each creature.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him whose high law not Varuṇa nor Indra, not Mitra, Aryaman, nor Rudra breaketh, Nor evil-hearted fiends, here for my welfare him I invoke, God Savitar, with worship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May they who strengthen bliss, and thought and wisdom, and the Dames’ Lord and Narāśaṁsa aid us. That good may come to us and wealth be gathered, may we be Savitar the God's beloved.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So come to us our hearts' desire, the bounty bestowed by thee, from heaven and earth and waters, That it be well with friends and those who praise thee, and, Savitar, with the loud-lauding singer. Next: HYMN XXXIX Aśvins. Sacred Texts Hinduism Index Sanskrit Rig-Veda, Book 2 Index Previous Next Buy this Book at Amazon.com Rig Veda , tr. by Ralph T.H. Griffith, [1896], at sacred-texts.com

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: UPRISEN is Savitar, this God, to quicken, Priest who neglects not this most constant duty. To the Gods, verily, he gives rich treasure, and blesses him who calls them to the banquet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So come to us our hearts' desire, the bounty bestowed by thee, from heaven and earth and waters, That it be well with friends and those who praise thee, and, Savitar, with the loud-lauding singer. Next: HYMN XXXIX Aśvins. Next: HYMN XXXIX Aśvins.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Moving at morning like two car-borne heroes, like to a pair of goats ye come electing; Like two fair dames embellishing their bodies, like a wise married pair among the people.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like to a pair of horns come first to us-ward, like to a pair of hoofs with rapid motion; Come like two Cakavās in the grey of morning, come like two chariot wheels at dawn, ye Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bear us across the rivers like two vessels, save us as ye were yokes, naves, spokes and fellies. Be like two dogs that injure not our bodies; preserve us, like two crutches, that we fall not.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like two winds ageing not, two confluent rivers, come with quick vision like two eyes before us. Come like two hands most helpful to the body, and guide us like two feet to what is precious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as two lips that with the mouth speak honey, even as two breasts that nourish our existence, Like the two nostrils that protect our being, be to us as our ears that hear distinctly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like two hands give ye us increasing vigour; like heaven and earth constrain the airy regions. Aśvins, these hymns that struggle to approach you, sharpen ye like an axe upon a whetstone.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These prayers of ours exalting you, O Aśvins, have the Gṛtsamadas, for a laud, made ready. Welcome them, O ye Heroes, and come hither. Loud may we speak. with brave men, in assembly. Next: HYMN XL. Soma and Pūṣan. Sacred Texts Hinduism Index Sanskrit Rig-Veda, Book 2 Index Previous Next Buy this Book at Amazon.com Rig Veda , tr. by Ralph T.H. Griffith, [1896], at sacred-texts.com

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING like the two press-stones for this same purpose; come like two misers to the tree of treasure; Like two laud-singing Brahmans in the assembly, like the folk's envoys called in many places.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These prayers of ours exalting you, O Aśvins, have the Gṛtsamadas, for a laud, made ready. Welcome them, O ye Heroes, and come hither. Loud may we speak. with brave men, in assembly. Next: HYMN XL. Soma and Pūṣan. Next: HYMN XL. Soma and Pūṣan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: At birth of these two Gods all Gods are joyful: they have caused darkness, which we hate, to vanish. With these, with Soma and with Pūṣan, India generates ripe warm milk in the raw milch-cows.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma and Pūṣan, urge your chariot hither, the seven-wheeled car that measures out the region, That stirs not all, that moves to every quarter, five-reined and harnessed by the thought, ye Mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One in the heaven on high hath made his dwelling, on earth and in the firmament the other. May they disclose to us great store of treasure, much-longed for, rich in food, source of enjoyment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: One of you Twain is Parent of all creatures, the other journeys onward all-beholding. Soma and Pūṣan, aid my thought with favour: with you may we o’ercome in all encounters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pūṣan stir our thought, the all-impelling, may Soma Lord of riches grant us riches. May Aditi the perfect Goddess aid us. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly. Next: HYMN XLI. Various Deities. Sacred Texts Hinduism Index Sanskrit Rig-Veda, Book 2 Index Previous Next Buy this Book at Amazon.com Rig Veda , tr. by Ralph T.H. Griffith, [1896], at sacred-texts.com

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SOMA and Pūṣan, Parents of all riches, Parents of earth and Parents of high heaven, You Twain, brought forth as the whole world's protectors, the Gods have made centre of life eternal.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pūṣan stir our thought, the all-impelling, may Soma Lord of riches grant us riches. May Aditi the perfect Goddess aid us. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly. Next: HYMN XLI. Various Deities. Next: HYMN XLI. Various Deities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O VĀYU, come to us with all the thousand chariots that are thine, Team-borne, to drink the Soma juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drawn by thy team, O Vāyu, come; to thee is offered this, the pure. Thou visitest the presser's house.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra and Vāyu, drawn by teams, ye Heroes, come today and drink. Of the bright juice when blent with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma hath been shed for you, Law-strengtheners, Mitra-Varuṇa! Listen ye here to this my call.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both Kings who never injure aught seat them in their supremest home, The thousand-pillared, firmly-based.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fed with oblation, Sovran Kings, Ādityas, Lords of liberal gifts. They wait on him whose life is true.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With kine, Nāsatyas, and with steeds, come, Aśvins, Rudras, to the house That will protect its heroes well;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Such, wealthy Gods! as none afar nor standing nigh to us may harm, Yea, no malicious mortal foe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As such, O longed-far Aśvins, lead us on to wealth of varied sort, Wealth that shall bring us room and rest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Verily Indra, conquering all, driveth e’en mighty fear away, For firm is he and swift to act.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indra be gracious unto us: sin shall not reach us afterward, And good shall be before us still.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From all the regions of the world let Indra send security, The foe-subduer, swift to act.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O all ye Gods, come hitherward: hear this mine invocation, seat Yourselves upon this sacred grass.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Among the Śunahotras strong for you is this sweet gladdening draught. Drink ye of this delightsome juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye Maruts led by Indra, Gods with Pūṣan for your bounteousest, Hear all of you this call of mine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best Mother, best of Rivers, best of Goddesses, Sarasvatī, We are, as ’twere, of no repute and dear Mother, give thou us renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee, Sarasvatī, divine, all generations have their stay. Be, glad with Śunahotra's sons: O Goddess grant us progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Enriched with sacrifice, accept Sarasvatī, these prayers of ours, Thoughts which Gṛtsamadas beloved of Gods bring, Holy One, to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ye who bless sacrifice, go forth, for verily we choose you both, And Agni who conveys our gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This our effectual sacrifice, reaching the sky, shall Heaven and Earth Present unto the Gods to-day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In both your laps, ye guileless Ones, the Holy Gods shall sit them down To-day to drink the Soma here. Next: HYMN XLII Kapiñjala.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: TELLING his race aloud with cries repeated, he sends his voice out as his boat a steersman. O Bird, be ominous of happy fortune from no side may calamity befall thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the falcon kill thee, nor the eagle let not the arrow-bearing archer reach thee. Still crying in the region of the Fathers, speak here auspicious, bearing joyful tidings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bringing good tidings, Bird of happy omen, call thou out loudly southward of our dwellings, So that no thief, no sinner may oppress us. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly. Next: HYMN XLIII. Kapiñjala.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: HERE on the right sing forth chanters of hymns of praise, even the winged birds that in due season speak. He, like: a Sāma-chanter utters both the notes, skilled in the mode of Tṛṣṭup and of Gāyatrī.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou like the chanter-priest chantest the Sāma, Bird; thou singest at libations like a Brahman's son. Even as a vigorous horse when he comes near the mare, announce to us good fortune, Bird, on every side, proclaim in all directions happy luck, O Bird.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When singing here, O Bird. announce good luck to us, and when thou sittest still think on us with kind thoughts. Next: HYMN I. Agni.
